block.p: The war between the HD-DVD and Blu-ray formats rages on, but it is still quite difficult to find PCs and laptops that can handle either of the new standards for high-definition video.
The Sony Vaio VGN-FZ180U/B, a $2,149 notebook with Blu-ray built in, is one of the first examples of this next-generation technology to reach the market at a less-than-astronomical price.

The war between the HD-DVD and Blu-ray formats rages on, but it is still quite difficult to find PCs and laptops that can handle either of the new standards for high-definition video.
The Sony Vaio VGN-FZ180U/B, a $2,149 notebook with Blu-ray built in, is one of the first examples of this next-generation technology to reach the market at a less-than-astronomical price.

This 5.75-pound laptop has a 15.4-inch screen and is about 1.4 inches thick. In its most powerful configuration the laptop has an HDMI-out port for transmitting HD video to a compatible television and an Nvidia GeForce 8400M GT card, one of the latest generation of mobile graphics processors, to power the entertainment.

In this configuration the FZ180U also includes a Blu-ray reader and even a burner -- a fairly exotic addition. It can handle up to four gigabytes of memory and has Intel's new Core 2 Duo processor at its heart, running at about 2.4 gigahertz. The battery lasts about two hours on a charge.
If the format wars find you leaning toward Blu-ray, the FZ180U just might be your weapon of choice.
